assessmentNote:
Proposal is relevant to the challenge considering it addresses token swap. Cardona being a multi -asset platform it is a must to have a native DEX for the tokens on the Cardano platform. 

Effectiveness of the proposal should be based on functionalities and economic model of the proposal. Functionalities of basic DEX are well discussed but the economic model and other important factors required to attract more people to the platform would be needed for assessing the solution better. Also there is a  need to attract people to  invest in liquidity pools unless EAMM has a solution to tackle the liquidity issue which is not very clear at this point in time.

The project appears to be a valid use design for this challenge although I am finding it difficult to give higher rating as it seems to be focusing on the preliminary stages (UI design). In which case I'm not sure the budget is aligned with the scope of the proposal.
Another DEX on the Cardano platform is a good idea.
This proposal is somewhat detailed (Gitbook documentation is lacking a lot) but I'm really missing an understandable planning to see how this team will implement on Cardano.

The proposal documentation is very uncomplete and lacking the explanation of the "EAMM" which they form their entire proposal value proposition around. The team needs to complete this technical docs and a Whitepaper/set of diagrams to describe this system.

The proposal goes into a detailed roadmap and the author has clarified the timeline of the project in a way that is realistic in the context of the scope of a DEX project. A diversity of projects of this type that are thoroughly thought out and attempting to build a new model of protocol for this purpose addresses the challenge.
Similar to Polyswap this proposal to build a DEX is interesting a definitely a must have for Cardano but is lacking a lot of detail in its current instance.
This proposal effectively addresses the challenges

I do believe the team are on the way to becoming capable of designing this proposal although by their own admission they have only recently begun to research other models. They do appear to have the necessary skills to further develop their understanding. I feel they would benefit greatly from exposure/interaction with the IOG team.

UI/UX experience is good to test initially but the roadmap of the solution to achieve the end goal along with clear product information is much more important. Assessment based on the end product functionality is something that I will give more wieghtage . 

Good to see that various phases of the project are being mentioned. A brief description of each stage is necessary to have clarity in terms of deliverables which is missing. Also, there is a missing stage for testing. It would great to have testing with the community possibly with the test tokens before going live. This test phase would help the product to be more robust and well-prepared for Go Live.

DEX isn't a novel idea thus there is reference available in the current crypto environments so it is important to have clear information on the steps involved. Thus more research and information needs to be furnished.

Team capabilities seem to be up to the mark considering experience in relevant products and native tools on Cardano though reference to completed projects and more clarity in terms skill would have had better impact. Considering the team lead is involved in multiple projects he might spread thin thus making him less efficient.

It is good to see there is research done to bring out the disadvantages of DEXs in other systems. Also it is implicit that DEX on Cardano will not include high gas fees but a clear economic model would suggest better on how the fees on the platform will be  minimised for best end user experience.
The proposal seems to effectively attempt to address the cosmetics of the project before the actual implementation, and leaves the community in a high risk position.

The Milestones in Phase 1 are extremely vague and not at all fully scoped. The amount requested for only Phase 1 milestones does not balance. It's also not at all clear who will develop this dApp in Plutus.
The proposal provides very little plan, development roadmap, Plutus dev resources highlighted or implementation metrics for the community to assess progress.

After seeing some explanations and review of the author's overall engagement in the community, and taking into account the timeline that has been provided regarding goals and funding, I think this project regards its goals correctly as medium to long term and is competent enough to adapt to the challenges this effort will most certainly bring going forward.
The proposal has a project roadmap and metrics to track development/implementation over time.

Good information provided although it does appear that this proposal is still in the early planning stage. This should not preclude it from being encouraged but I do have some concerns that have not been fully satisfied such as the budget.

The proposal provides a high level overview of existing DEX on other platforms and an initiative is taken to understand these technologies at a high level. 

A white-paper on DEX EAMM Protocol would be very useful in analysing the effectiveness of the technology being considered. I understand the work is in progress as the section is yet to be updated. The EAMM protocols seems to be the backbone of the solution thus having it available will boost confidence of the advisors. If not a whitepaper a more detailed information or illustrative flow charts or diagrams would help us understand the approach better.

EAMM will be a good to have with the discussed features in the proposal while the product will still be valid as long as it provides the swap capabilities but there needs to have clear definition of the backend technology used.

Wether the DEX will integrate with the existing wallets on the Cardano platform(Daedalus & Yoroi) or a new wallet will be designed for the purpose. It needs more information to answer such questions.
50k for the UI/UX is not an effective investment. Having the logic of the system exclude the EAMM protocol does not make immediate sense.

This proposal is lacking technical documentation fully unpacking the protocol components. The milestones in the project are very high level and the proposer spends more time describing existing protocols than describing how Cardax will be implemented.

This proposal is still lacking the technical documentation, detailed project plan, budget and metrics that a complete dApp solution should have for CA's to assess how effective/feasible implementation on Cardano will be.

This proposal has laid out a detailed timeline and milestones, has addressed concerns raised in its comments, and has demonstrated a reasonable level of contextual knowledge of the problems that are presented by this proposal's goals. It also is accurately recognizing a DEX as a long term project, which is important for its probability of success.
Please consider partnering with the Polyswap team you are essentially building the same thing.
There is a detailed roadmap, with milestones and clear goals.
This website can effectively serve as proof points to give assurances to prospective proposers.

The description of the proposal as-is does address the challenge by streamlining results information in a clearer manner, however the lack of additional detail doesn't demonstrate how effective the proposal could be.

Since the goal of this challenge is to attract new entrepreneurs to Catalyst, I think this proposal is in the wrong category. It rather addresses people who have already found Catalyst. However, the idea itself is a good one would make the start on Catalyst easier, as I think the front page of Catalyst could be improved.

The proposer is aiming to create an accountability tracker for all funded projects within project Catalyst. While this monitoring system is desired, it does not fit the category challenge and will not attract potential proposers within the next 2 funds. It is also known that Product Manager of Catalyst is looking into creating a tracking metric that can be shared with community.
The proposal aims to create a reporting and tracking website for funded proposals, not bring new proposers into catalyst in the next 2 funds.

Although the idea presented is interesting, it doesn't address the challenge. The idea presented is related to "auditing" from previous Funds and there is no relation to the reach of new entrepreneurs participating in Catalyst. I recommend that the proposal be submitted to a more appropriate challenge.
The submitter seems to clearly have the experience required to complete this proposal.
The plan is fairly light-on. If the site had already been started, or integrations with other similar endeavours had begun then that would be a stronger proposal.

The proposer provides evidence of his ability to create a website. There is no sensible plan, just an idea/suggestion what he wants to do. Also the budget is not described in detail, so I am not able to say if it's reasonable. As Catalyst provides at least a PDF after each funding round, the budget seems too high for me compared to the additional value that could be created.

The proposer is seeking 72% of the total funds available for this challenge, making this a less attractive proposal for voters. The proposer has experience creating open source projects, therefore they have a chance of starting this project on their own, or perhaps seeking funding next round in a more applicable category.
The goal and timeline of the project cannot feasibly improve proposer outreach and bring new proposers into catalyst.

There are no details on previous professional experiences and qualifications of the proposer/team, I recommend including this information and a link to Linkedin and Github.

The plan presented is simple and reasonable, but I think it is important to clarify what kind of information regarding the funded proposals will be made available on the website.
There is some detail missing on how the information will be effectively retrieved, and how they plan to keep up to date.
There is a lack of real metrics to measure success and demonstrate sufficient ROI
The funding is for one year. So I guess that the proposer will be updating this page permanently during this period. This could be understood as a roadmap and somehow a KPI to measure the progress.
The proposer does not provide any detailed information on budget and timeline breakdown. The proposal could also benefit from a list of KPIs in order to understand what minimum result is desirable.
The goal of the proposal is not inline with the Proposer Outreach challenge's goals.

The proposal described doesn't address the challenge. There is little information to indicate the feasibility of the proposal, I recommend the inclusion of roadmap, milestones, KPIs, details on professional experiences and team qualifications and details on budget allocation. I recommend following the Catalyst guidelines and documentation to write the proposal.

I'm not sure if I love this or hate this. :) I hate this if you are only asking 80,000 USD for your product development and then sell the end product back to the community that helped you develop it in the first place.

I love this if it:
a) offers something that Ledger, Trezor etc don't offer (please indicate what makes this special).
b) becomes a dedicated HW by the community for the community.
c) works seamlessly together with Yoroi / Daedalus and offers a way to secure / stake / vote / trade.
d) could allow the community to invent new solutions on top of it (use cases for e-signing, MFA etc). -> If this is voted to be implemented, I would even suggest you to set a challenge for one of the upcoming funds.

Thanks for this proposal, security and trust is a key element to widescale adoption of ADA. Without adequate security and trust ADA adoption will be slowed in both the enterprise and consumer space. I think this proposal fits the Fund 4 challenge as it potentially impacts the adoption of ADA across the entire ecosystem.
This proposal does not address the dApp creation challenge at all, a hardware wallet is not a dApp and also  benchmark to Cardano already supported HW wallets: Ledger/Trezor.
Adding security solutions to the ADA community - especially 3 factor will benefit the community
Team seems to be ready to roll up their sleeves.

The team has an existing product in development and is asking for funding to integrate ADA onto its platform with the hiring of an engineer for the development of integration for existing ADA wallets. They have secured a seed funding round after participating in the dlab accelerator program https://dlab.vc/, which is a positive indicator that the team is solid. More information needs to be provided as to the team. How many developers and their experience? As the current state of development and testing has been using software, providing detail about the progress, funding availability, and development of the hardware component would be very helpful to assess viability of success. What is the status of the hardware component production? What do you anticipate the hardware component will cost? Price will certainly impact adoption/use/sales.
After looking up the proposers I am more confident this product is feasible
There is no project plan, budget breakdown or technical doc included in this proposal.
The company seems to be bonafide security specialists and inspire confidence
The budget is missing. There are no metrics mentioned. Risks are not analyzed. Pricing for Project Catalyst members / ADA holders / others?

I suggest educating the community with some data or research about the problem of crypto security and the enterprise market size. It would enhance the proposal and provide context on why your proposal should be funded. How many individuals and companies are reluctant to use crypto solutions due to lack of perceived security and loss/theft of passwords? Will the hardware component be economical and/or priced for widespread adoption?
The product definitely addresses a problem that inhibits widespread adoption of ADA and cryptos in general, but I suggest more information about the team, hardware component development and pricing, and educating about why your solution is important for adoption.
The proposition seems unfinished and vague with respects to deliverables, time frames and other similar details.
The proposal is lacking all of the technical documentation required for starters, beyond this its not a dApp at all its for the development of an ADA HW wallet.
The website explains the product and security approach adequately to understand the feasibility
It seems like a thinly veiled phishing scam.

Proposal addresses the challenge but I think not effectively due to the involvement of a 'proprietary' licensed product. This casts a doubt on the future viability of the solution since licensing agreements end, are not perpetual and details could change upon renewal.
This proposal is not sufficiently detailed in any way that would be effectively addressing the challenge. It's also not clear why Cardano developers would want a tool that is not open source.

This proposal focuses more on infrastructure than on growing a vibrant developer ecosystem. It also doesn't demonstrate that the Cardano db-sync is inadequate for the current needs of developers. It doesn't make clear how the Cardano developer community could successfully employ this capability in their solutions. Since it is based on proprietary technology, it seems like developers would need to license it.

There is no clear requirement in the proposal. The technology mentioned like Knoxdb are not referenced anywhere. Not able to find any details of this technology. 

The proposal is lacking from the perspective of accuracy of information about the technology, skills and expeirience.
Exclusive access to a product that doesn't even show up in a google search "knoxdb bitcoin" is alarming.

Notwithstanding the 3rd party licensing issue of the proposal, the team seems to have had prior experience in developing similar solutions with big data and other blockchains and are familiar with the dev pathway
The proposal has no project plan, development budget or timeframe for implementation.
The proposal does not include quantifiable KPIs or other metrics that would define success. The team evidently does not have direct experience with the Cardano blockchain.
Even if this were true, it doesn't even clear up how it will benefit the community.

A breakdown of resources needed against the budget was not provided to give a clear indication of the time it will take to build the solution. Elements of what is required to be built has been provided but lacks detailed information on when milestones will be met.

This proposal is lacking all of information that would help me evaluate feasibility. There is little effort to explain budgetary requirements, nor timescales required to put this project to completion.
The proposal does not provide a justification for its budget. It does detail the team's experience, the development approach, and the general plan (though no roadmap for specific deliverables).
There hardly any clarity on the proposal about the problem being solved, the way technology will be able to solve it, there are references missing, a proper team and plan needs to be provided.
The proposal appears to address the challenge criteria and details how this will occur during development stages. I would like to see further examples provided.
The documentation included in the Miro board helps complete the picture of what they intend to deliver. A series of smart contracts around effectively completing a voting round.

I can see how an app that keeps track of a decision process can profit from the bockchain technology. If decisions of individuals are conserved in the blockchain, it is easy to track the process of an distributed decision process. The application might also be attractive to a wide audience. My only doubts are the costs of transactions on the block-chain that might make the whole decision process simly to expensive.

This proposal does not effectively address the challenge with no reference to past projects, technical docs or detailed development roadmap. The proposer also does not make it clear if the project will be built in Solidity or Cardano's native smart contract language Plutus.

This proposal provides none of the technical documentation or detailed project plan a dapp requires to be fully reviewed (Technical docs or Whitepaper both non-existent). The author mentions WP as step 1 but for the amount requested it should be the 1st thing listed in the proposal.

It was difficult to understand the definition of the problem you're trying to solve and your value proposition for solving the problem. The project title and problem statement are focused on distributed decision making, but the detailed explanation of the approach is about how developers can make Cardano more appealing to users and increase community involvement. It wasn't clear to me what is the connection between this idea and distributed decision making.
The proposal is well structured and this gives me some indication the team has the experience to drive the proposal forward. I would have liked a little more information about the team.

Beyond the relevant experience line the proposer provides little detail to make it clear how the project will be implemented. Not at al clear if this will be developed in solidity or plutus, for example.

The proposal lacks a detailed project plan, benchmark to existing voting dApps, links to the author's previous voting dapps mentioned, or basic technical documentation required to describe the protocol in detail.

This proposal has an excellent project plan: it shows very clearly how the funds will be used, the different roles and number of team members required, and amount of time expected from each team member. Your Github repository and Bchainify website also show that your team has a headstart on this project.
Reasonable information is provided and a solid timeline is evident. Perhaps a little more specific use cases would have assisted my understanding of the proposal a little better.
The miro board clearly showcases an effective delivery and evaluation strategy.
Good description in general. I think that a web-application is planned for the application. This information is missing.
The proposal provides lacking detail and it fails to make it clear why this dApp is even needed as an extension of the already existing Catalyst Governance process.
This proposal is early in the idea stage and is still missing much of the documentation required to be considered complete

The detailed project plan you provided demonstrates that this project is feasible to achieve. However, since the problem you're trying to solve was not elaborated in sufficient detail and had conflicting explanations, it's difficult to determine how success will be measured. Will this be measured through increased adoption of Cardano and increased community involvement, or through improved decision making? I think there's a risk that you might create a great product that one will use. You clearly demonstrated strong technical and project management capabilities, but I recommend elaborating on the business proposition (or value proposition) of the product or service that you're planning to build and why would the community use your products and/or services instead of comparable solutions from other teams.

I personally find this idea to be overlapping the already existing tools for voting and information pools. Personally I beleive that we shouldn't create new and increased tools as much as the community should focus more on improving the already in place tools we have. With the more options we give the harder it is to track overall and the more growing concern of trust of which interface/portal is best to access through.

If I understood correctly you wish to replace ideascale with a purpose-built dApp. Now, what does it have that Ideascale doesn't? What exactly do you wish to improve? I don't feel that you have managed to answer the questions raised in the Comments section (WHAT, WHY, WHO etc).
The proposal addressees the challenge but lacks detail in the plan or any metrics to track progress.

This proposal fails to make it clear how its any different from the Voltaire governance features already made available via Catalyst. This proposal is also submitted across multiple challenges w/o any meaningful changes per challenge submission.
Proposal aims at creating a mobile dapp/website as an alternative way to vote on proposals. By creating a different way to interact with Project Catalyst, proposal hopes to increase activity.
Although as well as it may be presented the  idea, I just don't believe in creating several of the same tools. I would agree if it were to improve the ones we have already.

You say you have a Team Leader, a Project Manager, a Front-end Developer and two Back-end Developers. That's great. Who are they and why is this team the best possible combination to take it forward? Who else do you need?
I believe the author has a good grasp of the concept but the project plan lacks detail, there is no technical documentation and its not clear what metrics the author considered.
Project plan is not detailed and there is no technical documentation attached to describe the system components in depth.

Plan is clearly presented and cost breakdown is sufficient, but I am not convinced that an alternative on-chain voting app will be easily deployed by the team. If the voting would be off-chain I don't see the difference between proposal and Ideascale.
I may not be in agreeance, but the overall plan is well thought.

So, after three months you wish to have 5 proposers (participants creating ballots) and 100 voters (active users) on your dApp - and this would be a parallel / optional process to Project Catalyst? Unclear.
This idea is difficult to properly assess as the proposers have not really detailed the how.
Proposers request 80% of the fund for this proposal. It addresses the challenge, but I fail to see a big differentiator between it and Ideascale.

There is no link to Github repos or previous implementations and its not at all clear why the proposer requires ~$87500 to create a DAO or how this will differentiate itself from the normal Catalyst/Voltaire governance features.

The proposer fails to make it clear how this is furthering Cardano's developer ecosystem or even differentiating from the Voltaire governance features that any developer will have the ability to build into their app.
Voting and governance are not pertinent to this challenge

This proposal reads like it is a dapp not a dev ecosystem tool, in addition how does the author never decide to reference the entire point of Voltaire is to deliver a library of governance features for Cardano app devs.

Tools and library used by community voters, other users like projects moving to cardano, AGI community, dapps from eth moving over, new developers joining cardano as the news spread, success in community advertise free and fast
there is no link the dapp author mentions several times in the proposal. Also no benchmark to Voltaire functionality...
The proposal has very little information to assess the capability of the team. In addition they list a working dApp but no link is included here or in the comments section.

This proposal fails to make benchmarks to Voltaire functionality, there is no link to their "working dapp" included either. Other basics not included are technical docs, metrics or implementation KPI's.
Creating a "accessible open-source decentralized library" to mange ideas and tasks in 4 months sounds highly unreality.. the plan offers no technical details on how the proposal could be implemented
None of the author's previous experience claims can be verified as they include 0 links to the working dApp
Progress monitoring and adjustment as needed, support from communities, then testing till success

given the ask amount this roadmap and budget is not sufficient, also please see comment above. In addition to these points please include some benchmarking to Voltaire (e.g. what are you doing differently) and basic metrics for CA to better review your team's capability.

There is no clear value add or even implementation approach associated with this proposal. It's also not clear how this proposal differentiates itself from Catalyst/Voltaire governance features already in development.
this proposal is missing key details/documentation and is also in the wrong challenge category. please review my comments above.
The proposal is not relevant for this challenge.
this proposal is not complete: no benchmark to Voltaire, metrics, or clear explanation on how developer's in the Cardano ecosystem will utilize the product.
Detail give inportant what, when, where and how, well articulated

The idea for LCCS similar to the Social Clubs of the 20s seems an interesting concept to me. However, that is not the main issue that comes up with this proposal. 
The segment "Describe your solution to the problem" in this proposal directly states: "I propose that the Cardano Foundation match funding that LCCs generate/raise/earn. "
However, the campaign brief for F4: Local Community Centers sets out that the Contribution of the Cardano Foundation and team members includes: 
Business development & marketing expert, Legal expert, Technical integration expert, Communication & community expert
The proposed solution to the problem: "I propose that the Cardano Foundation match funding that LCCs generate/raise/earn" deals with how the Cardano Foundation should invest its funds. This seems to lie outside the scope of the brief. 
The challenge specifies that proposals should address "How can we mobilize the community to solve local problems using Cardano, through a Local Community Center model supported by the CF?" This proposal's solution deals more with how the CF should mobilize its funds.
If the challenge is to encourage local engagement, funds are required either for space, refreshments, material or other event related expenses. If CF were to fund-match, that would encourage growth.

The problem statement is not really a problem, it could be re-written in a clearer way. I found the proposal idea to be a bit confusing, since it seems to be a suggestion to Cardano Foundation, and it is not clear if it is related to the budget or not. If the idea is to use the required budget to match the raised value in local communities, it is very good, the but text could be rewritten to emphasize that. Also, a lot of the discussion seems not to be directly related to the proposal, but it would be good to be moved to Discord server to work it with others.
Nowhere in this proposal is it made clear where a local community center will be established. All this proposal asks is for matching funds.
The proposer spends little time talking about the LCC they are setting up and most talking about CF's need to match them, strange.

Given the experience and the plan presented by the proposer it does not seem likely to me that this proposal will be implemented successfully. Effectively, the proposer states "I propose that the Cardano Foundation match funding that LCCs generate/raise/earn". As the proposer does not seem to be affiliated with the Cardano Foundation, to me it is unclear how this proposal will lead to a result in which the CF will "match funding that LCCs generate/raise/earn". It might be a noble idea if realized, but I am not clear on how can voters participating in Project Catalyst vote on funding allocations that are exclusively in the competence of a separate legal entity such as the CF.

The proposal didn't necessarily need to address how individuals or local groups will go about raising their own funds within or without the Cardano community, but some parameters or suggestions would help here. i.e. if my friend gives me $500 via paypal, will CF match that? or does it need to be documented/submitted in certain ways?
This proposal is lacking a budget, detailed plan or any semblance of metrics to track implementation.
There is no roadmap, plan, budget or general proposal strategy included in this idea other than get matching funds from CF

This proposal is entitled "Fund Matching from C-Foundation" and it suggests that the Cardano Foundation should apply its funds in a certain way ("match funding that LCCs generate/raise/earn") that seems to be outside the brief. We have no information from the proposer about the inside budgeting operations of the CF and whether a simple vote on this proposal has any impact on the allocation of CF funds. With this lack of critical information it seems difficult to confirm its feasibility - apart from engaging in a bit of "wishful thinking" about the CFs reaction. 
As regards the funding that is requested for this proposal (Requested funds in USD 30000), the proposers states "Funds will go to the other proposals in this category." If funding is being directed to other proposals in this category, to me it is unclear why the proposer is requesting funding from Project Catalyst.
A very simple premise that really needs no further explanation. If a basic framework can be provided for CF to "say yes" then I think it's a great use of treasury funds.

Roadmap, milestones and KPIs are missing. The proposal as a whole could be rewritten so that the proposal is clearer and part of it could be further discussed in the Discord server. By making the proposal clearer, it would also be it possible to create relevant KPIs and other metrics. Auditability should consider also a way to mitigate errors and malicious actions
This is an empty proposal requesting matching funds from the CF however the author never made the case for how they will establish a single community center before receiving matching funds.

To me this proposal seems rough around the edges. Although the requested funds are relatively small, it still does not seem sufficiently well presented. The proposed solution seems to be based on a donation model [ Give away for a couple of Ada. People come, setup wallet, receive Ada and "pay" for product. ]. Narrowly speaking it does provide help to a very small subset in a local community (consumers and sellers of a certain product), but does it automatically translate into " strengthening the community", apart from the proposed transactions? It does certainly help to implement the transactions as long as there is funding for the donations, but does it really further adoption after the initial donation is spent? Apart from the donated ADA, I am not convinced that it will result in the creation of a LCC - Business center (solving a local problem) that is sustainable - based on Cardano.

The described approach would help to spread the word about Cardano but I don't see how this would lead to strenthing local communities. It seems more like a way to bring attendance to the company of the author.
So the plan is to give people ADA that they can then give to you and you give them some alchemy in the bottle? I'm sorry... what?

The idea in general is good, although it will have a relatively low impact and we think in the whole ecosystem and local communities centers, but I believe that some interested people could start their 'crypto life' by this initiative. Some suggestions are: change 5 ADA to the equivalent price of the bottle, since we don't know how much one ADA will cost by the time this is implemented; also, I don't see a need to create a event specific wallet, maybe Yoroi could be used for this.
that will attract more scammer , ada giveaway !!

There is no description of how the proposal will address the challenge in a relevant way. The idea presented is to to ADA giveaways to encourage people to use the wallet, there is no mention of a Community Center.
It is a very simple proposal with a very simple solution, i am not sure if it is needed to address the challenge as the challenge itself isn't very concrete

The plan is limited in scope and seems it could be implemented, on the face of it. But, at the same time the issue I have with the likelihood of successful implementation is the lack of details about the proposer and the nature of the proposer's links to the local businesses that are being mentioned, as well as their true interest for participating. My impression is there is not sufficient information to convince me of the likelihood for a successful implementation.
Giving away some adas wouldn't be a big challenge. The wallet creation process must be explained but I'm pretty sure, this will be managed.
Umm, I am super confused about this proposal. Tokenizing a bottle sounds like fun though. Perhaps tokenized bottles wouldn't be thrown away so easily.

Proposal is relatively simple to implement, which is very good. Not a lot of experience would be needed. I'm not sure if the proposer is somehow related to the mentioned store (Aramen), but even if it is, I don't see if as a problem.
they are enough fake ada giveway we don't want to give them a legit appearance

Although the idea is extremely simple, the plan is not clear. What is the purpose to create a specific wallet? How does this idea involve Community Centers? There is no information about the proposer experience and its qualifications.
Although detail of plan is suggested i don't see any guarantee of how it can be implemented as organised.

I found myself desiring much more information about the proposal's feasibility and more data on how it addresses the challenge in question. I was not convinced about the true merits and feasibility of the proposal from the available information.
The challenge is not really solved by the suggested measures but I think that the succested measures can be implemented by the proposer.
I'm curious to know: what exactly will you get with that 1,337 USD? It's a very specific sum.

In this case, I don't see need for roadmap and milestones, since it is a very simple proposal, but KPIs need to be included. I believe a single KPI should be use most of the requested fund to distribute amongst new participants. Auditability could be done by tracking new generated wallets and the ADA transactions related to the proposal.

The idea doesn't address Community Centers. There is not enough information to check the feasibility. I recommend that the proposal be rewritten based on the Catalyst guidelines/documentation and be submitted in an appropriate challenge.
there are perhaps too little information provided.

The main question posed for the "F4: Local Community Centers" is "How can we mobilize the community to solve local problems using Cardano, through a Local Community Center model supported by the CF?"
The proposal that has been put forward does not address the aspect of "Local" in "Local Community Centers" well enough, in my view. The proposed solution "A collab platform for community-driven content production based on content models with built-in token-based governance on content and models" does not define the "Local Community" well enough in my view.
The campaign brief specifies that:
The different LCC categories are: (1) Developers center, (2) DeFi / DAO center and (3) Business center (solving a local problem).
The concept of "community" used by the proposer seems to me to be too vague as I am not sure does the proposer view his/her platform as an LCC and which type exactly? "The goal is to allow the community to participate in the decision making process and content creation." 
The proposer does not directly classify his proposal into one of the three, but does specify the following: " To address this problem, we are proposing a collaborative platform to organize community-driven content production".
It leaves me unclear whether by proposing a collaborative platform, this effectively means that none of the three LCC categories has been chosen, or one of them? We are left without a clear answer to what might seem a basic question as it is in the very title of the challenge.

I must commend this proposal for addressing a crucial challenge for the Blockchain network. However, I think you can start by limiting the amount of languages you want the content creators to work on. Why? I believe that this project is going to concentrate on a certain region. I assume south America. 

Pick the top spoken languages in Brazil. Keep it small and target your marketing towards those groups.

The proposal appears to answer the challenge quite well in that it will educate others in an interactive manner. This may flow on to ideas being generated that will further enhance Cardano knowledge in the community.

The proposal is very well presented and the sub-structure with Infoblocks is already in place to build upon an existing platform. Education is one of the biggest challenges for this project as the blockchain can mystify individuals that have no way of understanding the technology, the pros/cons and the greatest opportunities that can be unlocked with a little clarity. I like the idea and the solution it presents. Establishing governance is also a very good principle to include and the community has all the tools needed to build on a platform like this. The only thing I would say to the contrary is that an outline for the various stages needed to get there should be good to follow the progress of the project along the way.

The proposal model for content creation is very interesting and has the possibility to be sustainable in the long run. Also, it creates a mechanism through which the equilibrium between content creation and demand will be equilibrated. It seems to be scalable as well, and in the best scenario it could even be used globally and also replicated to other knowledge areas.

Not sure this sits in the right challenge, but it's a good proposal that would help drive Cardano adoption by engaging the existing community at different levels of expertise ( basic users, developers, and technical experts) and would likely bring in new users.

Your proposal does a great job of defining the challenge and explaining your proposed solution to address the challenge. Certain elements of your proposal demonstrate superior due diligence for this assessment area:

--Detailed and clear explanation of the problem you're trying to solve, including references.

--Detailed explanation of the process workflow to produce the desired output, including the roles and responsibilities involved and the steps each contributor needs to complete in the process, unlike other proposals that skip the business processes and jump straight into the technical development details.

According to the relevant experience segment filled in by the proposer: "Our team has been exploring for 6 months the challenging task of educating people about Cardano's technology through the Infoblocks project."
I also visited the link provided by the proposer: https://everyblock.studio/category/infoblocks/
I looked into the "About Us" segment of the website to gauge the relevant experience and was unable to immediately find anything more specific than "We are builders..." "Despite the cutting-edge technology we work with, EveryBlock Studio is primarily a creative space." etc... 
The project does propose to engage the services of: a Web Developer, b Blockchain Developer, c. UI/UX designer. D. DevOps. e. IT infrastructure. This means that critical persons would be onboarded. 
However, the weakeness may be the proposer's own relevant experience to run a project of this nature as this experience seems to be elusive. In fact, the specified experience "exploring for 6 months the challenging task of educating people " does not seem to be such that "it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully", in my opinion.
Unfortunately, there is no mention of the work experience of the proposers. A little background would help reviewers see who is leading the project.

I do feel that the team is likely to have sufficient knowledge to move the proposal forward however it is unclear where they will be sourcing the team or in fact whether the team already largely exists. Only a minor concern.

Given the extensive proposal brief, set metrics, breakdown on the different departments and the ideas presented with the solutions in principle as well as already existing formats created by the proposer there is confidence that the proposal will be successfully implemented.

The proposer seems to have enough information creation experience, although the proposal will demand more technical knowledge, which will be provided by the team described in the cost structure, which is not already engaged (at least it was not mentioned). The budget is well described as well.

The existing webpage (infoblocks) is built with high standards. The plan to use this as a starting point and to develop the user/community interaction is plausible an well described. The timeline and budget requested are realistic.

One of the main advantages of your proposal is that you already have a working product which you are now planning to "decentralize" and expand it to the community as a platform that can grow. Your Infoblocks website demonstrates that you have the technical ability as well as the right approach to explain complex technical concepts using web pages (e.g., the explanation you provided on how stake pool rewards are calculated). The other elements needed for a high score in this assessment criteria are all there, such as a high level plan and budget, a committed team in place, and demonstrated experience (again, my assessment assumes that you'll use your current Infoblocks website as the foundation for this project).

The project does specify that it " is expected to be developed over 6 months with Brazilian workforce" , but the feasibility of it does not seem to be addressed sufficiently, in my view. It relies on a wide range of diversified contributors contributing to the collaborative platform, however it would be good to have some metrics, some quantitive goals for this period that would allow for the measurement of success or failure. The project specifies that for each content (Infoblock), the team will create an infographic distributed as a static image, a base text detailing the content in more depth, a video with simple graphic animations and narration based on the text. But the proposal does not address how many infoblocks will be produced, how many contributors will be onboarded and other metrics - which makes it difficult to assess feasibility of outcome.

There are steps towards creating a system that works but we need to include storytellers to the mix. Your product needs a story that would stick with those it is trying to reach. Please include marketing in your budget. Sell this project better. It still needs some work.
Well written proposal with good evidence provided and I felt I was able to have a clear understanding of what the proposers are trying to achieve. Budget is reasonable without clarifying all aspects.

There is enough information here to be confident in the proposal and the metrics and work needed to actuate is are well described. The community has the potential to collaboratein the building of the solutions.

Roadmap is somewhat described, although milestones definition would increase the auditability of the proposal, and also the definitions of KPIs. Valuable KPIs in this case would be the platform usage, number of views, content quantity, and others similar.

The risk is that there won't be enough people interested in generation content or enough user interest. An incentive system is described which would work but the proposal didn't didn't success criteria or KPI's

Your project has reasonable feasibility based on the foundation you already built with the everyblock.studio website and the plan you proposed, but you need to describe the anticipated risks and how you plan to mitigate those risks. Also, I think it will be difficult to define measurable metrics to determine the effectiveness of your project: how would you propose to measure how the project is improving education about Cardano? At a minimum you should measure effectiveness by collecting feedback from the users and having a process for evaluating the feedback; for example, having a "Was this article helpful?" link that the user can click on to provide feedback.

My impression is that this proposal does address this challenge - BUT only in very general terms. The Campaign Brief states "Quality Dapps and integrations will increase utility & adoption of Cardano." 

What I am missing in this entire proposal is the "Quality" part. And it is a critical part. Throughout the proposal there is not enough detail to support the conclusion that this proposal will address the challenge in a fashion that will ensure quality. It is not only the idea (ADA Job offer platform) that is being assessed, but how well the proposal in its entirety addresses the challenge.

The proposal is a platform for hiring freelancers, but there is no detail on how the idea will address the challenge. The problem statement doesn't make sense, I recommend a problem statement modification and that the proposal be detailed.

The idea is good. But there is hardly any pointers to understand how the technology will be used to deploy project. Also clear definition of the solution are missing like who will this platform serve. For example 
Is it only for Cardano developers or open to all?
Where will be blockchain used in this solution ?

The proposal requires more information as to how the challenge will be tackled in the funding stage. A more clear metrics of how the solution is deploy can increase the chances of providing support towards the goal presented.

As an idea this proposal has merit and can be beneficial to the adoption and development of Cardano. However, the proposal does not provide any details by which its effectiveness can be measured. A platform onto which Cardano dev work can be published and from it, resourced , is key to Cardano meeting its goals but the mere mention of the platform is not enough to properly assess this proposal.

The problem statement could be improved: "high demand for blockchain-related projects" is not a problem by itself, but the lack of tech people to work on it might be. A platform lke this could be useful, as some of this discussions occur in other places already and one place like this could facilitate the process. Although, there are already general purposes platforms like this that could be used for this purpose as an alternative, with very low energy spending.
I feel it didn't clearly state the problem it looks to address and I don't quite get it until I read the proposed solution.

In theory - I can see where this may be headed. But author makes very little effort in developing this idea a bit beyond just basic concept. I miss bigger picture here - how author things about where all this fits within goals of cardano - nor how do we can determine its impact. Needs a bit more effort as it lacks many elements at the moment.
The idea of the proposal is interesting, i.e. a marketplace to match talent with enterprise, unfortunately in it's current state it's just an idea, needs a lot more work to reach a proposal stage
Not much information is given to address the challenge.

The listed experience as "software engenieer"  and the proposed plan seem to be (in my view) to be too bare bones for me to be able to assess that "it is highly likely that this proposal will be implemented successfully" - based on the available information in the proposal.
There is no description of a plan and there are no details about the proposer's experience, so it is not possible to assess the chance of success.

There is no clear plan in the proposal. Skills and experience relevant to platform is not demonstrated. More research and work in required in the proposal. Getting in touch with community developers might help
It's highly unlikely this proposal can deliver the work needed to implement the solutions appropriately without a structured map of the various progress stages needed to accomplish the task at hand.

The proposer has not provided details of past experiences in building such a platform nor presented his credentials with examples of work and past developments to give confidence it can be implemented successfully. There's no timeline nor milestones provided to properly vet this proposal.

The proposer is a software engineer, which is good, but to create a platform like this, specific knowledge for web development might be needed. Details about the budget are missing, and also a better description about the plan itself.
It didn't explain clearly about how strong the experience and background of team it has in order to achieve its objectives.

There is not enough information in this proposal to make it understandable how we can execute it. There really isn't a sensible plan in place and budget that would match that requirement. There is only one figure but it doesn't explain anything. Nor there is any attempt to validate experience needed to carry out this project.
Too little information is given to see the realisation of the proposal becoming successful.

In my view this proposal lacks sufficient information on feasibility. Also, while it does address the challenge in general terms - it does not include specific metrics and milestones, threats and challenges .

There is no information detailing the proposal in general, it is a draft, which makes it unfeasible and there is no way to evaluate how the idea will address the challenge based on the information described, details and a plan are needed, I recommend following the Catalyst documentation to prepare the proposal.
Information provided doesn't provide any clarity about the technology, roadmap as well as outcome.

The idea is good, I would advice joining with other projects proposing similar objectives, this can help increase the effect of the idea and the challenge can enrich the other teams also working towards solving this issue. The more like minded individuals connect in their interest for improving the system the better the results and the more robust the platform will be.

There is insufficient information in the proposal to properly assess its viability and effective deployment. Whilst such a platform is in the best interest to Cardano and its future growth, this proposal does not contain a development & deployment plan, the resources required to build the platform and the timelines for each milestone until its release. Besides, there are other complexities in such a Human Resources platform (legal, ethical, etc) and none of these were addressed.
Roadmap, milestones and KPIs are missing. Alternatives like using existing platforms might be considered. A detailed plan linked to the required budget could also benefit the proposal.

There is no roadmap or milestones to specify step by step plan. The objective is too board and it didn't explain how to assess success.
There is no breakdown or clear demonstration to explain how the 5000USD funding will be used.

Since these is very short worded proposal - it lacks naturally elements that would support it further - no roadmap, milestones, success metrics, challenges, risks. All of these need to make it into this proposal before we can seriously consider investing in it. We need to be able to understand it as a community.
No detailed roadmap is presented, no KPI's and no budget breakdown.
Not enough information is provided to make a high score judgment,.

It's a good proposal to gather new people who are interested and will contribute to Cardano community. And yes, reaching out more young people to understand what Cardano & Project Catalyst would be one of the option to grow the community.

The idea behind this proposal is essentially strong, but feels like it hasn't been fleshed out and streamlined sufficiently - in my view. The name of the challenge under which it was filed is "F4: Proposer Outreach" - hence, to me, the main weakness of the proposal can be summed up by the fact that it does not really mention or dwell on the "proposer".
The specific type of proposer who is the direct target of this challenge are "entrepreneurs from outside the Cardano ecosystem". Not only the general German population, or the student population. Yes, of course, proposers are to be found among them, but a more guided focus on Proposer Outreach would have been good, in my view. 
Popularizing Cardano is a noble goal, but a bit more focus on attracting enrepreneurs specifically might have improved this proposal further and strengthened its chances. I would not be discouraged if this proposal does not pass (it may!). If it is not selected now, flesh it out with more details and with the "uncaptured proposer" in mind.
As one of the most advanced economies in the world, being able to spread the Cardano message across Germany would very likely have positive impact to the Cardano ecosystem.

The focus of this proposal is to educate students about Cardano and Catalyst. So it can be seen as within the challenge setting. Explaining the potential of Cardano (here for the german audience) can be an important contribution to the community.

The proposer is aiming to create an online information hub with additional marketing to target German students in order to educate them on Cardano. This will not include anyone outside of German community who arent students. In addition, it appears the project will require more time to gain traction, and will miss on next two funds, therefore 2 stars.

It's a great challenge and the proposed solution appears to be a great start to develop a platform for Germans interested in learning about the project can promote the efforts of the community. Focusing on student is a great way to start as through intellectual initiatives they can find the value in understanding the technologies and could form teams to develop more presentations and ideas to be on the spotlight.

Whilst the proposal has merit and benefit to the targeted community there is an issue about longevity and the maintenance of the solution past the graduation of any students involved. However, the motivation of the students is a good counter to the lack of experience. Provisioning of information to a language other than English is required for Cardano to achieve its goals of being a global protocol.

With that budget and the target market is student/young people who use website & mobile phone, this proposal could be implemented successfully. It would be great if more German universities or students now about Cardano & Project Catalyst. And how this will change the community in Germany in the future.

This proposal seems to benefit from the enthusiasm of the proposer and the declared links to students studying entrepreneurship. However, while the proposal may be implemented successfully -  a website and the hosting of events "that make Cardanos vision visible for all Germans" - it is also a question whether building a website can "make Cardanos vision visible for all Germans" - among other initiatives. A build it, they will come model my not work the best in terms of Proposer Outreach - it might, but the proposer should make the case for hs idea. Also, education about Catalyst is only one aspect of Proposer Outreach. The company involved has not yet ben founded, the proposer mentions that for some tasks he "can share no references yet" - in responses to comments. Some additional metrics or ideas on how to assess whether the proposed plan would work - would have been welcome (Did we get proposals from outside our ecosystem through our initiative - and how to we know?)

The plan is vaguely described and it's not clear what experience the proposer and his team have regarding Cardano, or even technical experience on the development of websites, videos and effective advertising.

It is a team of students and they describe themselves as not experienced but as motivated.
They idea is to create content (website, explain videos, webinars) in german but they could not provide any references yet. With the information given I have to disagree, that there is a high probability that the proposal will be implemented successfully.

The proposer appears to be working with a team of students with a similar vision who are eager to break the stereotypes of crypto within their circle of influence. Given low start up costs, this project has potential to materialize and become successful.

The presence of abundance in the proposer circle funding could bring together an implementation strategy that brings confidence to the community. The breakdown of the funds distributed across the stages appear reasonable. The proposer has revealed experience in programming and the team and course explored seams to have the drive to do so.

The proposal should be commended for itemising the budget but it fails short on providing information on the timelines, development milestones and content of the website. As a student project within the field of study, the lack of experience in implementing such a resource is not in question. However to gain a higher rating, additional information is needed including the number of participants and the respective skillset of the team members.

Yes, the proposal provides quite sufficient information on how feasible it is. It would be more easier for the voter, if the proposer added what is the KPI of the project & how many events they want to hold within that budget.
I think that this proposal lacks  sufficient information to demonstrate how effectively it addresses the challenge. It seems that it could benefit from additional detail and milestones.

There are no roadmaps or milestones presented, no description on what content will be presented in the websites and videos. There are no performance or success indicators (i.e. how many students to you intend to reach with this proposal)

The team does not provide any metrics to measure progress and success of their approach. How many students do they want to reach? How many new proposal should be submitted? What is the time horizon of the project? What can the community expect as a result? The proposal does not appear to be mature yet.

The proposer provides sufficient information breaking down their expenditure of funds requested. The proposal is lacking an approximate timeline before a certain result is achieved, and does not include any KPIs to monitor the success.

More information on what subjects will the proposal cover and how many universities and social circles will the materials produced by the proposal will be implemented. More clarity expanding on the metrics surrounding the reach expected to be delivered from the project and other areas outside institutionalized circles and unexplored potentials would be interesting.

There is not a lot of detail provided to enable proper tracking of the developments and its results. Additional information in terms of timelines, skillsets, metrics (e.g. click rate on website) and most importantly content is required. I don't want to fully discourage this proposal as it has the foundations of being a very much needed resource to the approximately 130million German-speakers in the world. But its off to a good start. I hope this is expanded further for serious consideration.
Interesting idea and willingness to work with other proposers but what is actually being proposed... I don't know.
Not clear how this addresses the challenge

I think is a great idea to harness the community with different experiences and integrate passions with a focused centered approach on resolving challenges that may be required but are not well equipped or resourced to handle the work involve to do it right. More information or perhaps clear metrics as to the platform needed to make it work, management and changes needed to be implemented to make this work.

This proposal is lacking all of the technical documentation, description of protocol components, benchmarking to current/upcoming dev platforms for Cardano newcomers and any notion of a budget describing work activity.
This proposal is greatly lacking detail and reads like one of the several developer hub platforms already in development.
No clear picture of how this proposal will attract or create a favourable eco-system for developers, Idea looks so broad

The proposals describe interesting tool for attracting and educating new developers. In my understanding the challenge of attracting new developers is separate from the task of improving the experience of existing of existing developers. While the scope of this proposal falls close to the aim of "developer ecosystem" challenge it does not address it directly. Therefore, the proposals that fall closer to the aim of the challenge should be prioritized. The improved version of this proposal would be a valuable contribution for future challenges.

financially self-sustainable network and
Profits realized by the business are reinvested in the business itself (or used to start other social businesses networking), with the aim of increasing social impact, for example expanding the company's reach, improving the products or services or in other ways subsidizing the social mission.
Unlike a profit-maximizing business, the prime aim of a social network business is not to maximize profits (although generating profits is desired). Furthermore, business owners are not receiving any dividend out of the business profits, if any.

On the other hand, unlike a non-profit, a social business is not dependent on donations or on private or public grants to survive and to operate, because, as any other business, it is self-sustainable. Furthermore, unlike a non-profit, where funds are spent only once on the field, funds in a social business are invested to increase and improve the business' operations on the field on an indefinite basis. Per Yunus' quote: "A charity dollar has only one life; a social business dollar can be invested over and over again."

This proposal does address the issue of how can application developers drive adoption of Cardano in 2021? The question of whether this proposal is submitting a "Quality Dapp and integration that will increase utility & adoption of Cardano"  remains open in my mind. I am not convinced by the proposal as it seems a worthy goal, but many issues can be found:

- if the proposed index, a measure to be used as a baseline of value, is such a valuable idea - why hasn't it been developed yet. 

This proposal not only looks at the new idea as a concept, but also proposes to integrate it to a blockchain. However, many arguments are laid out that seem to be partly wishful thinking:

-  The market will have confidence that standardized prices for BHN commodities are accurately established. 
- Producers can use the Item Banc Engine's data to determine where the most profitable markets are to export their products, to properly hedge their production and inventories. - - The financial markets will have a better way to value currencies. 

These are claims with far-reaching consequences for this project, but are based on suppositions and as such I am not sure about the "Quality integration" part of the proposal.

This is an interesting idea, to create an index pegged to real world data that is constantly updated by users. But to me it still sounds like a centralized solution that is only using Cardano as a reward system.
I believe in the vision of this project's potential, a little ambivalent about how it can be used in a system effectively is my personal concern in deploying this wonderful tool.

Here is the framework for how I estimate the level of IMPACT for the new Challenge for Fund6: 
1) Is this a wicked problem that has not been addressed in previous challenges? 

While IOG is clearly focusing on creating a bridge to Cardano from Ethereum with their ERC-20 converter and K-EVM, and side chains. There are almost certainly many, many more ways that we the Cardano ecosystem could benefit from additional bridges and interoperability with Ethereum. A huge amount of the expertise in Blockchain is working in the Ethereum ecosystem. So bridges and collaborations between chains would be beneficial to both. 
2) Is this addressing a "green pasture" opportunity that could improve the well-being across a major region or globally? 

At this point in time I would also say that there are only a few truly compelling use cases in the Ethereum ecosystem. It is true that it is a new financial system, but to date it is mainly a speculative one for trading money and focusing on short term gains. The real value is in delivering high fidelity systems that translate well across the world and bring in people and resources that are currently ignored, devalued or inaccessible to the current financial system. Right now Ethereum is mainly useful as a new form of trading for fintech bros, macro wonks and gold bugs. So the main benefit would be by attracting developers. Useful, but as in the island, pond and ocean analogy there probably is actually a lot more talent and expertise elsewhere. 

3) How much will the requested funds catalyze this effort and produce a meaningful result over the next few years? 

The amount of funds requested are the entire community challenge amount. This should be significant enough to really foster interest, buzz and community support around the effort. I personally don't like that the whole fund is being requested, but to stay faithful to my assessment it actually would be a huge statement about how serious Cardano is to bridging to Ethereum.

My framework for this assessment for how suitable this challenge is as follows: 
1) Product-market fit: is this a wicked problem that is has a lot of demand, is uniquely suited to Cardano or if done successfully will really set Cardano apart?

This has great product-market fit. Very similar to porting IOS games over to Android. With the tools that IOG is providing to help bridge the gap, there is already a foundation to build on and probably a lot of benefit to providing people an easy way to try out the Cardano blockchain for work they have already done in Ethereum. 

2) Circle of competence: is there enough competence and passion in the ecosystem so proposals will have great leadership and synergy between team, partners and/or community?

This one is hard to assess. Right now, the blockchain community is very tribal and dominated by maximalism. I think this is changing, but it is very possible that the Ethereum community has a lot of entrenched loyalists so could be hard to establish bridges. That said, there is also a tremendous amount of entrepreneurial energy in blockchain which means people will want to roll with the latest and greatest tech (which Cardano is, right!?). So creating support and focus on inviting those entrepeneurs to bridge to Cardano could have a very large upside.  

3) Accelerators: Are there clear network effects or other advantages that will drive success?

Yes. Ethereum is the largest blockchain, smart contract development ecosystem right now. Success in creating ethereum bridges and collabs would probably have a large positive ripple effect

Micro loans and DeFi are niches aligned with Cardano's mission, but technically I see no sense in limiting the scope of the challenge for Africa. The needs for financial services in Africa are largely due to the large number of unbanked and exploratory lines of credit. DeFi solutions for this type of problem require dapps and undercolateralized loans and to obtain these types of loans, decentralized credit score projects are required. The point is that the solutions to this problem are not geographically restricted, so limiting the scope of the idea to the African continent doesn't make sense. DeFi has no geographical boundaries. What prevents the use of DeFi for unbanked people and people with less purchasing power is the lack of undercolateralized loans and this will only happen with credit scores and preferably with the help of DIDs.

There is a high demand for microlending solutions on the African continent. 
It would significantly improve users' chances of becoming economically independent. 
The potential impact of this is extremely large for both users and the community, who would be enabled to create these DeFi and microlending solutions.
The documentation attached demonstrates how Cardano can solve real problems in the daily life in African countries like Kenya.
Helping developing countries find better financial solutions is one of Cardano's core missions, and this challenge obviously addresses that

I don't believe in the feasibility of the challenge at the moment, because in order for Cardano to have DeFi dapps that can provide undercolateralized loans, profile assessment / credit scores projects are necessary. In addition, in order to have functional dapps, some basic blocks in DeFi still need to be created, such as oracles. Liqwid itself is a possible solution to this problem, but it is still in development and it should still take a few months for its first version to be ready. So, for this challenge to be feasible, we need Goguen's delivery, money market dapps operating (Liqwid for example), functional oracles and credit score projects. It may be that these projects exist during the implementation of the proposals arising from this challenge, but it is an uncertainty that compromises the viability of the challenge.
As you have relevant experience and a team already in place, I see no issues with the feasibility that this proposed project would be implemented.

The community has the capacity to address technical side of the proposal. However, a much more difficult legal aspect of the idea has not been mentioned in the proposal. As loans must be repaid, there needs to exist a way of carrying it out within the local legal framework. To put it simply, the repayment obligation must be enforceable. This is well beyond the scope mentioned in the proposal.

I think that it will be very important to bring the right people together during such a Challenge Setting. Before creating any kind of dApps, I would expect a short-, mid- and long-term Masterplan as goal for this activity. Otherwise we might just jump on creating some kind of applications, which do not meet the complex technical economic, political and social requirements. I only have one improvement suggestion and that is to include the marketing goal in the title. What are we exactly going to market?

Well, MARKETING, this is a very general title. Successful marketing of rather complex technological products and services is a complex beast. Spending a lot of money is no guarantee for any success. Yes, marketing, advertising, opinion leaders, celebrities, all this is somehow important. BUT: Key is the underlaying ‚something', which needs to be touching real needs, desires and dreams. This is more about simple, self-explaining value propositions, culture, community and purpose. This needs to be authentic and cannot really be 'produced'. Not even with many millions and not with your estimated USD 400.000 (which would consume the entire funding of this campaign). Sorry for lecturing a bit, but I have quite some experience in this field. Successful Cardano marketing needs to be done in concert with IOG, the foundation and the community. This is important for growing our unique and authentic reputation. Experience shows, that sustainable reputation needs to be earned in a humble way, marketing/advertising can only be important accompanying factors. There are also other proposals posting similar Challenge Settings. We need to make sure that this leads to joining forces.

While I am aware that marketing can be very expensive depending on the media outlet, I am not convinced that we currently have the capacity to fully fill up the entire challenge budget, with high quality proposals, to fully make use of all of it. We also do not know how the future will play out with any "parabolic bull runs" and when any such would end, so I think references to such are unnecessary in the challenge brief. The expansion of Cardano-related content to non-English speaking communities is fully in line with Cardano's ideas. One of Cardano's main objectives is to be a protocol used by hundreds of millions of people and this will inevitably require a lot of information in several languages. There is a huge demand for this, including in Catalyst itself, because currently the vast majority of content related to Catalyst is in English and if we want to guarantee fair and considerable participation we need to propose solutions for translation.

To reach the whole world, multi-lingual approach is a must. However, as mentioned in the comments, what should be translated is the first question to be answered.

I don't see the "broadness" as an issue. After all, this is a Challenge, not a solution.

One approach would be to only translate what goes on the landing page: https://cardano.ideascale.com/a/dtd/Project-Catalyst-Landing-Page/341718-48088

Another approach would be to "organize globally" so that the local / regional / continental groups can deal in their own language(s) but the global collaboration still takes place in English, with representatives of the aforementioned groups functioning as "messengers between languages".
Making sure internationalization is top of mind across a growing is ultimately a requirement if we plan on becoming the de-facto world banking system.
The challenge aims to accelerate the adoption of Cardano worldwide. Decentralization will be enabled also in countries in which the uneducated population does not have access to resources in english.

Great proposal, the need to onboard multicultural agencies, user and organization is an integral part of the Cardano mission. The official page for Cardano already brings a multinational and multilinguistic  platform for all to share ideas, questions and resources. An expansion of this asset could well benefit the mission at large by facilitating the base foundation of the Cardano exosystem.
I think this is important to entice crypto "virgin" markets into Cardano, although English should always remain the global and common language of Cardano

This proposal aligns well with Cardano's mission. 
While English is the current Lingua Franca of the world, it is not the case in all regions and communities. 
It is in Project Catalyst's vision to include as many and as diverse a community can possibly get. 
It is important that we realise such an inclusion early on to maximise involvement and thus opportunity.

Definitely important to create multilingual resources. The estimated funding of USD 75.000 looks reasonable. For qualifying this to be a Challenge Setting, I would suggest to look closer, which global synergies and/or platform approaches can be created.
However multilingual resources are essential for the growth of the project, creating challenge for that doesn't seem much important at this stage.
completely agree Cardano ecosystem needs to reach devs/builders in more languages.

Yes, the community is able to propose solutions for this. But certain decisions need to be taken before we can tackle this (the scope, the tools, the process, the roles, the incentives etc).
The diversity of the catalyst community is primed for this undertaking

It appears that a basic form already exist and the substructure is there to build upon, the community has what it needs to welcome improvement to that challenge.

Decentralization is one of the key elements of the Cardano roadmap. I believe that allowing a self governance within the stake pool would accelerate the process.
This suggestion would provide a good answer to the growing number of pools, that are controlled by "big players". It brings the idea of decentralisation one step further.

An interesting concept for sure. I like the idea of these more automated stake pool operators where the decisions are not completely up to them, I think at that point they basically become providers of computing/networking resources. It could simplify the process and provide a lot of benefits to the ecosystem

I find the need to change how a stake pool operates a bit ambitious. I'm sure the governance system that was drawn out by the creators of these stake pools understood why these stake pool operators have people's stake in their care. They'd want to maintain their reputation of operating fairly and diligently. This ensures the trustless system continues. Besides, it's too much time to spend on the activities of a stake pool. It should be as mindless and less time consuming as possible. 

I'd advice you look at the idea again and think of how to refine it for the better.

It is a great idea, It creates governance within governance but I can see the opposite effect that could lead to the detriment of the pool itself. If there is malice it can also become a tool that can hurt the network. Not saying that it would happen but when we talk about humans banding together for whatever reason the possibilities exist. This can also impact on identity issues and the failure of one to affect others. I can see the immense benefits but also the detriments in this idea.

Interesting proposal, but not aligned with the challenge set for fund 6.
